Public Attributes

Status d_status

Detailed Description

Utility class to read and write ASCII configuration files.

The Config class provides a mechanism for reading and writing configuration files. Configuration files are ASCII files that contain an optional global section and subsequent named sections.

Configuration files are case sensitive. The elements of a config file are listed as follows:

Section Name (the name is enclosed in square brackets). 

 [MySectionName]

Blank lines (these are skipped).

Entries (begin with an alphanumeric identifier that conforms to C identifier name rules, values appear after the identifier) 

 mainWindowSize 30 40
 mainWindowPosition 20 10

Below is an example configuration file: 

 age 30
 name Nick
 occupation Lifetime Student
 address 315 EIB
 address0 Fluor Daniel Engineering Innovation Bldg
 city Clemson
 hours 8 4 3 4 2 3
 testMatrix3by2 1 2 3 4 5 6
 
 [Tooner]
 age 7
 name Tooner
 occupation Pet
 address 123 Cat Row
 city New York
 
 [Stinky]
 age 5
 name Stinky
 occupation Pet
 address 234 Cat Row
 city Chicago

Example Program: 

//========================================================================
// Project: QRTS Utility Classes
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------
// Package: Config
// Authors: Nick Costescu, Markus Loffler
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------
// File: Config.t.cpp
// Example program for the Config class.
//========================================================================

#include "Config.hpp"

#include <iostream.h>
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>


//========================================================================
// Global Variables
//========================================================================

const int c_numPersons = 3;
char name[c_numPersons][200];
int age[c_numPersons];

Config *myConfig;


//========================================================================
// loadConfiguration
//========================================================================

void loadConfiguration()
{
  // Load the configuration from the file
  myConfig->loadConfiguration ();
  if (myConfig->d_status.isStatusError ())
  {
    cout << myConfig->d_status.getMessageText () << endl;
    return;
  }

  // Get the entries
  for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++)
  {
    // Set section
    char sectionName[200];
    sprintf(sectionName, "Person%d", i);
    myConfig->setCurrentSectionName(sectionName);
    
    // Read entries
    strcpy(name[i], myConfig->getStringEntry("name", "default"));
    age[i] = myConfig->getIntegerEntry("age", 20);
  }
}


//========================================================================
// saveConfiguration
//========================================================================

void saveConfiguration()
{
  cout << "Saving configuration" << endl;

  // Set the entries
  for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++)
  {
    // Set section
    char sectionName[200];
    sprintf(sectionName, "Person%d", i);
    myConfig->setCurrentSectionName(sectionName);
    
    // Read entries
    myConfig->setEntry("name", name[i]);
    myConfig->setEntry("age", age[i]);
  }
  
  myConfig->saveConfiguration();
}


//========================================================================
// main
//========================================================================

int main ()
{
  myConfig = new Config("Config.t.cfg");
  myConfig->disableAutoSave();
  
  loadConfiguration();
  
  while (1)
  {
    cout << endl;
    cout << "---- Current List of Persons ----" << endl;
    for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++)
      cout << "Person " << i + 1 << ": Name " << name[i] << ", age " << age[i] << endl;
    cout << endl;
    cout << "Change which person (0 to exit): ";
    int num;
    cin >> num;
    if (num == 0)
      break;
    
    cout << "New name: ";
    cin >> name[num - 1];
    cout << "New age: ";
    cin >> age[num - 1];  
  }
  
  cout << endl;
  cout << "Save configuration? (yes, no)" << endl;
  char input[20];
  cin >> input;
  if (strcmp(input, "yes") == 0)
    saveConfiguration();

  delete myConfig;
    
  return 0;
}

Member Enumeration Documentation

enum errorCodes
 

These are the error codes d_status is set to in case of certain errors.

Enumeration values:
e_cantFindSection   A section was not found.
e_newFailed   An operation was out of memory
e_cantFindEntry   An entry name was not found.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

Config ( const char * configFileNameAndPath = 0,
const char * searchPathShellVariable = "CONFIG" )
 

The constructor initializes the configuratin file name (if given) and the search path shell variable (if given). See setFileName() and setSearchPathShellVariable() for more information about these parameters. The constructor does not load the configuration, this must be explicitly done by calling loadConfiguration(). If the configuration file name is not specified, setFileName() needs to be called before loading the configuration with loadConfiguration().

Example: 

       Config *myConfig;
       
       myConfig = new Config ("test.cfg", "CONFIG");

~Config ( )
 

The default behavior of the destructor is to save the current configuration to the currently specified configuration file. The disableAutoSave() method can be used to disable this default behavior (in this case the user must explicitly call saveConfiguration() to save the configuration file). If you have not specified a current config file name (with setFileName() or with the constructor), the file will not be saved.

Example: 

       delete myConfig;

Member Function Documentation

void setFileName ( const char * fileName )
 

Sets the name of the configuration file. Subsequent load or save functions will deal with this file. If you don't specify a path here (i.e., the filename does not contain a "/" character), then the shell search path variable (specified with setSearchPathShellVariable() with in the constructor) will be used to resolve the full path.

Parameters:
fileName   The filename of the configuration file

Example: 

       myConfig->setFileName("myconfigurationfile.cfg");

const char * getFileName ( void ) const
 

Gets the name of the configuration file.

Returns:
The name of the configuration file.

Example: 

       cout << myConfig->getFileName();

void setSearchPathShellVariable ( const char * searchPathShellVariable )
 

Sets the name of the shell variable that contains the search path for config files. Subsequent load or save functions will use this path to find the config file, if only a file name was specified with setFileName() (or with the constructor). The search path contains the absolute paths of all search directories, separated by ":".

Parameters:
searchPathShellVariable   The name of the search path shell variable.

Example: 

       // Look for the configuration files in the search path for binaries
       myConfig->setSearchPathShellVariable("PATH");

const char * getSearchPathShellVariable ( void ) const
 

Gets the name of the shell variable that contains the search path for config files.

Returns:
The name of the search path shell variable

Example: 

       cout << myConfig->getSearchPathShellVariable();

const char * getResolvedConfigFullPath ( void ) const
 

Gets a pointer to the resolved full path to the config file. If the user specified a path (including a file name) for the config file name, then that path (including the file name) is returned here. If the user specified only a file name, then the search path shell variable (given in the constructor or specified with setSearchPathShellVariable()) is set to) is used to find the config file. If the file is found, this resolved full path will have all of the path in it including the file name. If a config shell search path variable is not specified, the config file name will be returned.

Returns:
The resolved path of the configuration file.

Example: 

       myConfig->setFileName ("test.cfg");
       myConfig->setSearchPathShellVariable ("CONFIG");
       cout << getResolvedConfigFullPath() << endl;

If the shell variable CONFIG was set to ".:/usr/qrts/config", and there was no "test.cfg" file in the current directory, but there was one in "/usr/qrts/config", this method would return the string "/usr/qrts/config/test.cfg". 

       myConfig->setFileName ("/test.cfg");
       myConfig->setSearchPathShellVariable ("CONFIG");
       cout << getResolvedConfigFullPath() << endl;

Will output "/test.cfg" regardless of what CONFIG is set to because a path is specified with setFileName().

void loadConfiguration ( void )
 

Loads the configuration. File name and search path (if used) must be set prior to this function being called. If the name is not set, or the file can't be found, d_status will be set to error. Configuration items in memory will be overwritten by ones read from the file.

Example: 

       myConfig->loadConfiguration();
       
       if (myConfig->d_status.isStatusError())
       {
         cerr << "Can't load configuration file " << 
           myConfig->getResolvedConfigFullPath() << endl;
         abort();
       }

void saveConfiguration ( void )
 

Saves the configuration. File name must be set prior to this function being called. If the name is not set, d_status will be set to error. The file will be saved to whatever full path is returned by getResolvedConfigFullPath().

Example: 

       myConfig->saveConfiguration();
       
       if (myConfig->d_status.isStatusError())
       {
         cerr << "Can't save configuration to file "
              << config->getResolvedConfigFullPath() << endl;
         abort();
       }

void clear ( )
 

Clears and deletes all sections and entries.

Example: 

       myConfig->clear();

void disableAutoSave ( void )
 

Disables auto saving when the object is deleted. If disabled, you must explicitly save the configuration before deletion of the object. The default setting is enabled.

Example: 

       myConfig->disableAutoSave();

void enableAutoSave ( void )
 

Enables auto saving when the object is deleted. If you do this, the configuration will automatically be saved to the currently specified file name when the object is deleted. The default setting is enabled.

Example: 

       myConfig->enableAutoSave();

void createSection ( const char * sectionName )
 

Creates a new section at the end of the configuration.

Parameters:
sectionName   Name of the section to be created. If not specified, the default/global section is used.

Example: 

       myConfig->createSection ("Bob");

void clearSection ( const char * sectionName )
 

Deletes all entries in the given section in memory. Does not delete the section itself.

Parameters:
sectionName   Name of the section to be cleared. If not specified, the default/global section is used.

Example: 

       myConfig->clearSection ("Tooner");

void deleteSection ( const char * sectionName )
 

Deletes a section and all entries in it.

Parameters:
sectionName   Name of the section to be deleted. If not specified, the default/global section is used.

Example: 

       myConfig->deleteSection ("Bob");

void setCurrentSectionName ( const char * sectionName )
 

Sets the current section name. This name is used for all get/set entry methods that do not specify a section. By default, this is set to "global" by the constructor. Use the special name "global" to address the global section.

Warning:
Using this function in combination with any of the set..Entry(const char *entry, ...) and / get...Entry(const char *entry, ...) functions is not thread-safe. Instead, set..Entry(const char *section, const char *entry, ...) and / get...Entry(const char *section, const char *entry, ...) should be used in threaded programs.
Parameters:
sectionName   Name of the section to make current.

Example: 

       myConfig->setCurrentSection ("Tooner");

const char * getCurrentSectionName ( void ) const
 

Gets the name of the current section (to which all reads/writes pertain).

Example: 

       cout << myConfig->getCurrentSectionName();

int getNumSections ( ) [inline]
 

Returns the number of sections.

Returns:
The number of sections.

const char * getSectionNameByIndex ( int i ) [inline]
 

Returns a section name.

Parameters:
i   Index of the section (0 = "global" section).
Returns:
The section name.
Parameters:
<b>Example:<   /b> 

       cout << "List of all sections: " << endl;
       for (int i = 0; i < myConfig->getNumSections(); i++)
         cout << i << " " << myConfig->getSectionNameByIndex(i) << endl;

void enableAutoClearStatus ( ) [inline]
 

Enables the auto clear status feature. If this feature is enabled, d_status is automatically set to "OK" before each get...Entry()/set...Entry() function. The default is off.

void disableAutoClearStatus ( ) [inline]
 

Disables the auto clear status feature. If this feature is enabled, d_status is automatically set to "OK" before each get...Entry()/set...Entry() function. The default is off.

int isAutoClearStatusEnabled ( ) const [inline]
 

Returns if the auto clear status feature is enabled. If this feature is enabled, d_status is automatically set to "OK" before each get...Entry()/set...Entry() function. The default is off.

void setEntry ( const char * entryName,
T value ) [inline]
 

Sets a scalar entry of type T in the section that is specified by setCurrentSectionName(). If the section does not exist, it is automatically created.

Parameters:
entryName   The name of the entry.
value   Value to set the entry to.

Example: 

       config->setEntry("encoder", 120);

void setEntry ( const char * sectionName,
const char * entryName,
T value )
 

Sets a scalar entry of type T in a specified section. If the section does not exist, it is automatically created.

Parameters:
sectionName   The name of the section.
entryName   The name of the entry.
value   Value to set the entry to.

Example: 

       config->setEntry("encoder", 120);

void getEntry ( const char * entryName,
T & value ) [inline]
 

Gets a scalar entry of type T in the section that is specified by setCurrentSectionName().

See also:
The convenience functions getIntegerEntry(), getDoubleEntry(), and getStringEntry().
Parameters:
entryName   The name of the entry.
value   Value is set from the entry.

Example: 

       unsigned short int encoder;
       config->getEntry("encoder", encoder);

void getEntry ( const char * sectionName,
const char * entryName,
T & value )
 

Gets a scalar entry of type T in a specified section.

See also:
The convenience functions getIntegerEntry(), getDoubleEntry(), and getStringEntry().
Parameters:
sectionName   The name of the section.
entryName   The name of the entry.
value   Value is set from the entry.

Example: 

       unsigned short int encoder;
       config->getEntry("encoder", encoder);

int getIntegerEntry ( const char * entryName,
int defaultValue = 0 ) [inline]
 

Gets a scalar integer entry in the section that is specified by setCurrentSectionName(). If the entry is not there, d_status is set to error. If the status is error, the default value is returned.

Parameters:
entryName   Name of the entry to be read.
defaultValue   This value is returned if the value cannot be read from the configuration.
Returns:
The entry value.

Example: 

       int fillColor = config->getIntegerEntry("fillColor", 0);
       if (config->d_status.isStatusError())
       {
         cout << "An error occurred reading entry fillColor "
              << config->d_status.getMessageText() << endl;
       }

int getIntegerEntry ( const char * sectionName,
const char * entryName,
int defaultValue = 0 )
 

Gets a scalar integer entry of a specified section. If the entry is not there, d_status is set to error. If the status is error, the default value is returned.

Parameters:
sectionName   The name of the section.
entryName   Name of the entry to be read.
defaultValue   This value is returned if the value cannot be read from the configuration.
Returns:
The entry value.

defaultValue   This value is returned if the value cannot be read from the configuration.

void getArrayEntry ( const char * entryName,
T * data,
int rows = 1,
int cols = 1 ) [inline]
 

Gets the given array from the configuration in the section that is specified by setCurrentSectionName(). You must allocate the memory for the array.

Parameters:
entryName   Name of the entry to be read.
data   Pointer to memory you've allocated to store the array.
rows   Number of rows in the array (default = 1).
cols   Number of columns in the array (default = 1).

Example: 

       double matrix[3][3];
       config->getArrayEntry("myMatrix", matrix, 3, 3);

void getArrayEntry ( const char * sectionName,
const char * entryName,
T * data,
int rows = 1,
int cols = 1 )
 

Gets the given array from the configuration in the specified section. You must allocate the memory for the array.

Parameters:
sectionName   The name of the section.
entryName   Name of the entry to be read.
data   Pointer to memory you've allocated to store the array.
rows   Number of rows in the array (default = 1).
cols   Number of columns in the array (default = 1).

void setArrayEntry ( const char * entryName,
T * value,
int rows = 1,
int cols = 1 ) [inline]
 

Sets the given array from the configuration in the section that is specified by setCurrentSectionName().

Parameters:
entryName   Name of the entry to be set.
data   Pointer to memory where the values are stored.
rows   Number of rows in the array (default = 1).
cols   Number of columns in the array (default = 1).

Example: 

       double matrix[3][3];
       config->getArrayEntry("myMatrix", matrix, 3, 3);

entryName   Name of the entry to be set.
data   Pointer to memory where the values are stored.
rows   Number of rows in the array (default = 1).
cols   Number of columns in the array (default = 1).

Member Data Documentation

Status d_status
 

Used for error messages and status information. Note: For all of the get.../set... functions below that get/set scalar values, d_status is set to error in case the entry was not found. This won t affect further calls to the get.../set... functions (but d_status won t be reset to "ok"). After using a get...() function, the user should check d_status to see if there was an error which indicates the entry did not exist or was invalid.
